title: What “tricks” do lower level math teachers teach their students that annoy upper level math teachers? - Quora

response.answer_text: Taking the discussion way down to elementary school. I taught the advanced math group in upper elementary—fourth and fifth, mostly fifth. But I taught remedial math after school to third, fourth, and fifth graders. Here are some ot the things I begged lower grade teachers not to do: Do not say subtract the little number from the big number. This works fine when the child is solving 5 - 3, but when the child is older and solving 13–5, it results in 12 for an answer.Do not say, “Goes into,” for division. For example 12 ÷ 3 read as “Three goes into 12 how many times?” Often pronounced “Guzzinta.” It means nothing. If it did mean something, it would likely be addition. Instead, say, “How many groups of 3 can be made from a group of 12.”Do not read a fraction as “One over two,” or “Five over 12.” Instead, call the fraction by its name, “One half,” or “Five twelfths.” You could also say “One divided by two,” or “five divided by 12.” That would help us in the upper grades.I don’t mind if a child counts on his/her fingers, but please teach them to do it right. Have them say the first addend, then count up to the sum. For instance, 17 + 5. Say 17, then count 18, 19, 20, 21, 22. If you let them start counting with 17, they will say, “17, 18, 19, 20, 21,” end up with the incorrect answer. Same thing with counting down for subtraction.Never say, “Carry,” or “Borrow.” If solving 213 - 5, say, “Move the one ten to the ones column where it becomes ten ones. Add that to the three ones you already have, and then do 13 - 5. Your answer is 208.” Use manipulatives until they understand what they are doing relates to something in te real world, not just a trick with numbers.Also, please don’t say, when regrouping, “Cross out the zero and make it a 9.” Teach the child to understand what he/she is doing, again using manipulatives. If you don’t when a child is solving 4008 - 9, they cross out the zeroes, make them nines, and solve 4998 - 9.EDIT: Thanks, Elijah Liu, for your suggested edit, but 13 - 5 is the problem I want. When the confused child takes the little number (3), from the big number (5), he gets 2. Then he “brings down” the “1,” getting 12. If he had learned to recroup, he would have correctly gotten “8” for the answer. I’ve thought of one more pet peeve. 7. When reading a number, say 305 or 3,072, please do not say, “One hundred and two,” or “Three thousand and seventy two.” This is because, in the upper grades, we want the word “and” to be used where the decimal point goes, or to divide the whole number part from the fraction part of a number. For instance, “795.05” is read “Seven hundred ninety five and five hundredths,” and “27 2/3” is read “Twenty-seven and two thirds.” That’s enough for now.

Really, almost any shortcut that sidesteps understanding to grant more immediate success is a real frustration. This is why vertical alignment is really important. I’m okay with teaching the Pythagorean Theorem or Quadratic Formula without proof (these are pieces that can be picked up later), but most things are best presented in a way that makes mathematical sense. The knowledge will stick better, and teachers up the chain won’t have to reteach (AND UNTEACH) as much later. Here’s a concrete example:  When you’re trying to draw the inequality x > 4 on a number line you should shade the part of the number line that contains all of the numbers greater than 4.  Not terribly difficult. But… some teachers teach it like this: “If the arrow is pointing right, shade right. If it’s pointing left shade left.” What. The. #$&% ???  First off, this completely defeats the purpose. We’re trying to get them to visualize what “greater than 4” looks like. Not have them draw a random picture. Secondly, foiling this is very easy. Graph 4 < x? Oops… Then the next fun part is when we graph two-dimensional inequalities. How do you graph y > x + 5? “Do we shade to the right?” “We’re dealing with y, so it’s not left or right, it’s up or down. Which direction indicates more than for y?” “I don’t even know what that means…” [in my head] “Of course you don’t, because your teacher punted the ball.”  But “upper-level” teachers are guilty of this as well. (I’m guilty of this as well.) And honestly, if students are near the end of the line in their math education, application is more important than understanding, though in most cases understanding makes application easier.
